message: For those looking for a bite to eat at lunch, china town is quite close - two blocks west. There you can have some decent Yum Cha at Marigold or East Ocean (quick google for exact locations).
My recommendation would be Gumshara Ramen (inside "Eating World" in Chinatown), which has by far the best thick soup broth I've ever tasted: http://maps.google.com/maps/place?cid=3178745530153157863
What's that really awesome dumpling place near the SMC called? It's upstairs somewhere... I really need to go there again :-)
Also is anyone aware of a good Ethiopian restaurant that serves in the traditional style on a big ol' inerja?
Great choices Graham. Might need to book ahead though, and even then you might be trying your luck with queues/timing during PyCon
My choice for Dim Sum. http://www.zilver.com.au Have chinese wife so you don't argue with them when it comes to good food.
For Sushi. http://www.eatability.com.au/au/sydney/makoto-sushi-bar/
Well, the main PyCon evening dinner (Saturday) is taken care of. It's Sunday through Tuesday I'm thinking of. Though there'll probably just be Pizza At The Sprints at least once :-)
+1 on advice about Ethiopian -- north african food rocks
any suggestions on where to stay for pycon-au and the sprints
@kman you're best bet is to look at http://www.tripadvisor.com.au for reviews on close hotels in your price range.
A bunch of us are staying at the Ibis around the corner, but its prices for conference time have gone up over the last couple of days.
I second Graham's recommendation of Makoto for sushi -- some of the freshest sashimi I've ever tasted.
Hmm, as a local I haven't tried Makoto - will have to give it a go, love japanese food
With Makato, you can do take away. For sprint days you could always order in advance a sushi platter if really keen.
Other good take away choice is the seafood pie from Harry's Cafe De Wheels down Capital Centre. Presuming that is it is still there. Haven't been there fore ages.
@GrahamDumpleton I would love to go to that Dim Sum place.
Can anyone recommend a particularly good US -> Australia power adapter?
@pydanny power adapters are much of a muchness, the only real difference is the style (large vs small) and whether it supports ground (third prong).
@pydanny You mean just an adapter for plug, or an upscaling 110-240 voltage adapter? What sort of stuff is it for?
Meant 240-110V stepdown transformer.
I don't remember the name of the dumpling place @r1chardj0n3s mentioned either, but it really was great. IIRC, right on the corner as you come to the Chinatown mall
